review_title: Great mission, great people, improving strategy.
pros:
Great Mission:
Hands down, the best thing about working for the Sierra Club is that you're proud of the mission.  Almost all of the employees are working there for the right reasons, and that makes for a great day-to-day work life. A lot expected of employees, but you're only asked to work a hard 40hrs/wk. After that, the expectation is that you're out of the office enjoying your free time.

Ability to Make a Difference:
The Club is America's oldest and largest environmental organization. If you want to be a player in the environmental movement, this is a great place to be. 

Management Heading in Right Direction:
The senior management is much more employee-friendly since a leadership change in 2009. I've worked at the Club since 2007, and it's a noticeable shift towards transparency, efficiency, and collegiality.
cons:
The Club's size--550 employees and growing to over 700 by 2013--can be difficult to navigate. There are inevitable bureaucracy and communications issues. In particular circumstances, this can be incredibly frustrating. However, as mentioned above, senior managers seem very intent on addressing these issues.

Due to the Sierra Club's historic role as a catch-all environmental organization, the Club can spread itself too thin while trying to address every issue under the sun. This can lead to issues when staff are unclear about their priorities ("wait, which issue gets my precious time?"). Again, in recent years this focus has improved significantly, but there's still work to be done here.

pros:
Summary: I was a chapter employee but was able to work with national and regional employees and still felt very aware and enlightened in all three aspects of the organization. 

National Sierra Club: Pretty good salaries. Generous benefits, very transparent "ladder" to work up. Offers training and opportunities for advancement. The management and board are rooting for all employees to succeed and make themselves available for them to ask questions and seek improvement.

Chapter Sierra Club (Pennsylvania): Very dedicated board and efficient, mentoring type management.
cons:
National: Can't think of any.

Chapter: Always limited financial resources. It's hard to fund raise at the chapter level. I don't think this is the fault of the chapter, but rather in an environmental awareness "developing" state, donation dollars and resources were stretched thin. That said, they were always very appreciative of all the work I put in and tried to compensate accordingly through benefits.

cons: Very hard to move upward in the organization without sucking up or overworking yourself to endear yourself to your supervisor. Management training is basically non-existent. People are promoted based on seniority or popularity and not given the resources to learn how to manage. Salary is low for most people but was extraordinarily high for some senior executives who likely cost the organization more than they created in donations/etc. At the time, upper management/HR was very anti-union and would outright lie about how the contract limits them from giving promotions/raises/etc. New top level hires would not take the time to learn about the current structure or past of the Club and this would prevent them from being effective, but not from drawing huge salaries.

job_title: Various Roles In the Conservation Department in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Well, it's the Sierra Club and there are original Ansel Adams photos on the walls. Hard to beat it for history and respect. - the Sierra Club made the Bay Area's parks what they are. And they are effective to this day, which is not true of all environmental orgs (I've worked for more than one). 

Another good point is they tend to be pretty good to employees, so you can stay there forever. Again, unlike a lot of burnout enviro orgs. Benefits are better than average for a nonprofit.
cons:
The national office can be bureaucratic and turfy -- sometimes it's like working with the DMV. Lots of people telling you why something can't happen, nobody trying to help you. 

Under the previous CEO, management had a very antagonistic approach to their unions, which was a big problem. Unfortunately, perhaps because of that, I did not get much shared sense of purpose. The anti-union stuff led to antagonism and self-serving behavior. That came from the top, I think. 

There is a new CEO!

review_title: Great mission, wonderful colleagues .... but in an organization marred by a horrible sweatshop mentality.
pros: The Sierra Club offers  an opportunity to do work that really counts. It attracts vibrant, talented  people and the club's venerable stature is energizing. Communication is improving and the club is definitely working to break out from its old stifling bureaucracy. The future looks good in that regard.
cons:
...But...

The Sierra Club is a nonprofit ghetto for its staff.

The organization does not really seem to appreciate its people. Salaries are almost an insult -- even in the low-paying nonprofit world. Benefits range from OK...to deplorable.  The most ludicrous is the club's "vacation"  policy which seems stuck in the early 1900's rather than the 21st century. Two weeks for the first few years?  You don't see many organizations anywhere still inflicting that hideous burden on people even in the high paying corporate world.  In the non-profit world, its unheard of...and appallingly oppressive. 

Management now seems to be trying to raise the quality of life for the staff....but there's a very long way to go before reaching any sort of parity with similar nonprofits.

pros: Its fulfilling to work with passionate people, towards worthwhile goals, for an organization with a proven track record of getting things done. Generally you have a lot of autonomy and must be self-motivating, which provides good flexibility in your day-to-day work. The staff is unionized and has good health insurance benefits, bereavement & maternity/paternity leave, and flexible time off.
cons: The Sierra Club is an old organization, with many burdens of an aging and complicated bureaucratic structure. Field office and local Chapter relationships are unnecessarily separate and strained. Because of the expectation of self-governance, there is very little effective oversight for staff and volunteer leaders. Lazy and ineffective employees can remain in their positions for years, to the detriment of the the organization and staff moral. There are duplicate capacity structures, and silos of information that create division and confusion.

pros: Senior Management was professional and quick to acknowledge hard work done by outreach coordinators and the amount of time and effor they put into their jobs.  Some of the work I did, I felt like I was accomplishing something I was proud of and got the feeling I was making a difference in the world
cons: Lower-level management is a different story.  The ones I met and worked with had a holier-than-thou attitude, especially toward female employees. I felt like I was sent back to 1960 every time I went into the office with the way the men would treat me. There is virtually no opportunity for professional growth at this organization. Senior management is so far removed from the lower-level employees that mid-level managers are never punished or noticed for their poor treatment and bad attitude.

review_title: Working for an Environmental Nonprofit: Pluses and Minuses.

review_title: Great place to start your career...
pros: The people are incredible.  They are motivated, smart, fun and down-to-earth. Hard work is often recognized and rewarded with more responsibility.  This is a great place to work while you are young and interested in building a strong but diverse set of skills.
cons: Although hard work is recognized through opportunities to take on more challenging project/campaigns, it can be difficult to build a long-term career at the Sierra Club. Many of the organization's sharpest employees begin to look elsewhere in their mid-career because there are limited opportunities for upward mobility.

review_title: Old-school Org trying to step into the 21st century has ups and down
pros: Lots of fun and interesting co-workers, important and exciting mission-based work, opportunities for retreats and *some* professional development, flexible schedule (if you have a good manager), actively investing in new technology, many great teams to work with, well-organized union representation.
cons: Sometimes the organization feels too big for its own good. Difficult to grasp who is on point for what. Low accountability among volunteers. Internal processes can be messy and drawn out. Hiring new staff takes way too long. Some salaries are so low it's impossible to live off.  Difficult to keep track of what tasks asked of you are actually in your job description (be prepared to wear about one millions hats). Not enough effort to retain talent.

review_title: Great organization and values -- diplomacy skills & ability to navigate internal politics a must for success
pros: Passionate people, incredible resources available for running effective advocacy campaigns (legal, communications, political, and grassroots), and excellent politics. Sierra Club is one of the few national environmental organizations that is deeply committed to organizing and to building people power. It strikes an impressive balance between holding true to its core values, and being willing to make reasonable compromises in order to achieve real change. It's also making important strides in terms of prioritizing Diversity, Equity and Inclusion.
cons: Tough bureaucracy to navigate; figuring out roles and responsibilities between departments could prove tough. Volunteers play a critical role at the organization, which is a great asset and sometimes a liability since there's little consistency in terms of skillsets and strategy. Relationship and politics between National and Chapters can prove challenging.

review_title: If you want to make a difference, come work for the Sierra Club

The people at the Club are very passionate and that makes it fun.
cons: Saving the planet is hard work that never ends so it's a very demanding job and there are rarely enough resources to go up against the big fossil fuel companies.

review_title: Great organizational culture but lots of change happening now

pros: Staff is incredibly committed to the mission of the organization; fun atmosphere. All non-management staff have union representation. The organization is very strategic and effective, and in recent years has done a lot of internal work that is very progressive and focuses on building effective teams, networking and building coalitions with non-traditional allies, etc. I also have a lot of respect for the organizational culture and volunteer-led approach; the grassroots leadership of the organization is nothing short of inspirational.
cons: The staff has a tendency to over-work themselves. The salary scale compared to some comparable organizations seemed on the low side. Sometimes the organization has internal conflicts between different levels of volunteer leadership (i.e. national vs. state/local priorities), which can lead to some interesting challenges.

review_title: Excellent Place to Save the World
pros: The Sierra Club as a strong culture that emphasizes care for its employees as much as care for the environment. Staff are unionized with solid benefit system. And most managers believe employees should have flexibility to choose the best method for achieving their goals.
cons: Because many of the staff are community organizers, staff often aren't in the same office as their manager and may only meet in person with their manager a couple times a year. This can mean that career development opportunities are sometimes lacking and individuals who aren't self-starters won't do well.

pros:
Given real responsibility
Worked with me to make sure my learning goals were met
Flexible
Learned real world and applicable skills 
Supervisor was great - kept in great contact, always available, genuinely cared that interns were taken care of 
Lots of opportunities to continue involvement and move up in organization
cons: Unpaid, although not a terrible con as most internships are unpaid especially in a non-profit, but we still got $100 Meijer gift cards at the end of our campaigns. Thoughtful touch. So, no, really, no cons.

pros: The Sierra Club is a well very well resourced organization with a large influence in national, state and local governments. The organization is constantly evolving and strives to be innovative, open to change and self-reflective.
cons: The Sierra Club is surprisingly hierarchical for a grassroots organization organization.  Decision-making is not always transparent and sometimes the people responsible for implementing ideas are not adequately consulted. The organization is very privileged in its resources and wealth, and I don't think this is fully appreciated.

pros: Amazing non-profit with full focus on achieving tangible results and solutions to save the planet. Great people, great purpose, and *great* execution. Benefits are good.
cons: Organizer turnover is tough to manage, but at the end of the day, either you promote people up the ladder or pay them more.

pros: Mostly a peaceful and fun place to work. People are cooperative, kind and really care about the mission. Fairly relaxed environment without much micro managing. Decent benefits.
cons: Technologically behind in general with lots of extra work caused by the lack of up to date infrastructure and multiple systems that don't work well together. I am aware they are slowly improving this, but it is a bit painful. Also, many people are overworked much of the time.

pros: This organization has a fantastic union that works hard for its members.
cons: The Oakland office talks incessantly about diversity, but the only departments that seem to have more than one POC employee are the mailroom, and human resources. Hardly anyone at the managerial level is nonwhite. The office in DC seems to be much better.

pros: Dedicated team working to make positive change.  Challenges are in the realm of causes that are important and the teams and people involved are inspired and inspiring.
cons: Complexities of the larger organization's - national - resources not always trickling down to chapter needs creates confusion and sometimes disorganization.  Pressure for tackling an exhaustive amount of work.

pros: Working here is a transformative experience, at the state level you effect change at a grassroots level and if you are passionate about the environment this is a wonderful place to be.
cons: If there had to be a negative, I would say there is a bit of a disconnect between national and chapter offices. Specifically in regard to operational duties, information and process. From a program & campaign point of view there is. great deal of support.

pros: Great work environment and amazing employees. The work that is done at the Sierra Club is for an amazing cause, and is fulfilling.
cons: Nonprofits in general can be a little disorganized from time to time, and the Sierra Club is no different. But they also have a million things happening all at once, and have locations in every state in the US. So with that in mind, they still do an amazing job.

job_title: Program Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The work is relevant and exciting for someone who cares about the Club's mission.  Employees are fun and interesting, atmosphere is very laid back (but serious about its objectives).
cons: Relatively low salary - every employee could be making more in a similar position, sometimes even at other similar non-profits.

pros: Fun office environment, flexible hours for internships, lots of office perks and opportunities to participate in other events on the hill, very passionate about environmental issues.
cons: No compensation at all, not many opportunities to connect with other co-workers or senior level directors on a daily basis, takes a lot of initiative to get to know other people.

pros: Great organization to work for... management provides the opportunity for career growth and development and room for creativity.
cons: There is tension between the volunteer leadership and management. Often, decisions are made that are not necessarily in the best interest of the organization or the cause because of the lack of organizational focus and strategy-driven outcomes.

pros: Very supportive for interns and give projects with good amount of responsibility. Location in SF was great, but not sure how the new Oakland office is
cons: had only one email that we shared between all the legal interns. this made it more difficult to interact with staff because each intern had to sort through the others' mail.

pros:
Great cause and amazing successes
Wonderful people to work with -- smart, talented, dedicated
Opportunity to expand your job
cons:
Newer CEO has changed the culture from: 
--flat organization wth everyone feeling on equal ground to more hierarchical
--no more information sharing re: organization with entire staff to just select few
--from equality oriented to male-driven
--from an inclusive, broad-minded organization to a more elite, "pure-focused" organization
--from focusing on employees' strengths to focusing on trying to fix employees' weaknesses and evaluating them on those.

review_title: Great place to learn about state politics, work on your soft skills, help contribute to society.
pros: Great place to work if your just getting out of college and want to gain soft skills working with government reps, volunteers, and other enviro organizations
cons: Conservative political environments can make success near impossible when working on issue campaigns. In addition compensation is often not worth the hassle of public advocacy

pros: I completed the apprenticeship program for recent college grads. It was great hands-on training and I was able to play an important role in my department. I enjoyed working with my colleagues and I learned so much!
cons: At the time I was there, there were very few openings for program assistant (post-apprenticeship entry-level) positions, so I had to find work elsewhere after my apprenticeship term ended.

review_title: I got to work with people I cared about on issues that I cared about.
pros: People care about what they are doing, and the volunteers are amazing people. The Sierra Club can be incredibly effective at protecting the environment, and its power can be unappreciated by staff, volunteers, and allies.
cons: Advancement opportunities can be lacking outside DC and SF. Pay is decent for environmental work, but it is lacking compared to other progressive organizations.

pros: Incredibly dedicated staff who entrusted me with a lot of responsibility from the get-go, giving me the freedom to participate in the mission of the organization in my unique role.
cons: I was quite exhausted much of the time because I was incredibly busy (which I really am not complaining about - it was just quite an adjustment).

review_title: The guys with the money are in charge and they don't much care about you or the grassroots, just what they want done.
pros: Discover why environmentalism is so weak in this country. Lots of paper, copiers, and carbon based travel and trips.
cons: The staff are treated to ample time off, excellent salaries, and assignments forever - contrast that with the volunteers that come to the cause thinking they'll be able to organize. . They will get a clipboard and told they are now working on the latest National campaign that has nothing to do with their interest.

job_title: IT Systems Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some teams are strong and most of the people working there gel along well.
cons: There is a clear divide between management and workers, and who gets promoted is often based on personal politics.  Salaries are low even compared to other Bay Area non-profits and management always blames budget constraints (which don't apply when they give themselves raises or go on management retreats).

pros: Mission driven org, passionate co-workers;  good compensation relative to smaller nonprofits (unionized workforce elevates salaries/benefits for all), making an effort to address issues of equity, inclusion, and justice.  Would recommend to friend but with reservations/caveats.
cons: Departments fairly siloed with some more functional/supportive than others, high risk of burnout, limited opportunities for career advancement, still a long ways to go for true equity and inclusion within org.

good benefits

fairly well funded

pros: Motivated, enthusiastic, exceptionally talented coworkers; positive work culture with generous benefits for a nonprofit and union membership for most full-time employees.
cons: Most people commit a lot of time and energy to their jobs, which can make for high expectations around output and caliber of work.

review_title: Heart is in the right place, salaries are not living wages
pros: The Sierra Club leaders and volunteers really do have their hearts in the right places - they care deeply about the environment. Sure, there are the occasional internal politics but, for the most part, people here get along with each other and work hard.
cons: Needs some new, fresh ideas from upper management. Salaries need a significant boost to make them livable wages.

pros:
* Employees includes young, optimistic, motivated professionals
* Diverse work - opportunities from advocacy to legal
* Large member base that supports the club
cons:
* As with most non-profits, limited job opportunities and chances for upward mobility
* Again, working in this industry probably means relatively low wages and very high workload, particularly for entry-level jobs
* Diversity of Club members and employees [from this reviewer's perspective] is somewhat lacking

pros: The DC office has a bunch of awesome protest signs everyone, everyone very progressive and cares about the causes. My impression was of a workplace that respected and advocated for work/life balance.
cons: Office has a very open floor plan, so when making phone calls or coworkers having conversations, things could get loud/distracting. Work was sometimes stressful due to caring about the issues/being on a tight schedule to follow Congress.

review_title: Great, dedicated people doing good work
pros: Very dedicated and smart co-workers. People work a lot but there is good flexibility and lots of time off. The work is important and respected within the field.
cons: Pay disparity between chapter and nation staff. Unclear opportunities for advancement. Burn out is real.

pros: Smart, collaborative environment within department structures. Flexibility. Important mission.
cons: Certain departments have developed cultures that are not always collaborative; lack of bottom-up approach and protections for chapter staff results in conflict; stepping on toes; uncomfortable work environment at the chapter level.

pros: Flexible work environment. They have many great initiatives if you are involved in grass roots campaigns.
cons: Unorganized. People don't seem to be very happy. Way behind the technology curve. Takes forever to accomplish tasks. A lot of internal bureaucracy with many tall walls to climb across. Employees aren't held accountable for errors or accomplishing tasks. Communication is terrible and no one is on the same page.

pros: Very progressive and inclusive, Mgt actually gives a #$@%, good benefits, not great on he 401K match pretty low there but all the other benefits are great.  The best part is the people, their dedication and the great work people do.  Decent wages for a nonprofit.
cons: weak 401K match.

pros: Passionate employees, good benefits, a mission-driven organization that is seeing through one of the most successful campaigns of our time
cons: Long hours, no clear routes to advance, poorly trained and ineffective middle management, and funding conditions that don't match reality on the ground
